Graphical abstract MoO3 modified CeAlO x catalyst prepared by the facile coprecipitation method has been utilized for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The catalyst showed excellent activity, prominent resistant to the space velocity and exhibited high SO2 or/and H2O durability at 250°C. A series of MoO3 doped CeAlO x mixed oxide catalysts with different Mo/Al molar ratios were prepared by the simple coprecipitation method and used for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The Ce-Mo-AlO x catalyst with the Mo/Al molar ratio of 0.5 exhibited excellent activity and high H2O or/and SO2 poisoning resistance at 250°C. XRD revealed that the molybdenum oxide existed in either highly dispersed or amorphous phases on the catalyst surface. BET analysis results showed that the total pore volume and the average pore diameter of the CeAlO x catalyst was improved by the addition of MoO3. As determined by the H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, the redox capacity and total acidity of the CeAlO x catalyst were also enhanced by the introduction of MoO3, which are critical for the NH3-SCR reaction. The SCR reaction mechanism was also studied by the in situ DRIFTS, the coordinated NH3 and ionic NH4 + species together with the monodentate and bidentate nitrate were active intermediates on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst surface during the NH3-SCR reaction. Keywords Molybdenum modify NH3-SCR NO Reaction mechanism ; 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is the most feasible technology for controlling NO x emitted from stationary sources. The most widely used catalyst for the NH3-SCR process is V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 or V2O5-WO3/TiO2, which showed excellent catalytic activity and highly resistant to SO2 within the temperature range of 300–400°C [1,2]. However, some drawbacks still remain in the catalyst, such as the relatively narrow temperature window, high oxidation ability of SO2 to SO3 with increasing vanadium amounts and the toxicity of vanadium pentoxide to the environment and human health, etc. [3–5]. Due to the above disadvantages, many researchers have made great efforts to develop environment-friendly SCR catalyst with excellent performance, nontoxicity to the environment and high durability to the SO2 and H2O. Ceria based catalyst with the advantages of environmentally-benign, high oxygen storage capacity and excellent redox property has been proved to be a promising NH3-SCR catalyst in the future. Wu et al. developed ceria modified MnO x /TiO2 catalyst, which showed excellent NH3-SCR performance at the low temperature [6]. Ce-W-Ti mixed oxide catalyst prepared by Shan et al. using homogeneous precipitation method presented superior NH3-SCR activity and high CO2/H2O durability [7]. Ce-Ti oxide based catalysts were studied by Gao and He et al. which displayed excellent NO conversion and high tolerance to SO2 and H2O [8,9]. CeO2-MoO3 and MoO3-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were also developed by Li et al. all of which exhibited much better catalytic behavior compared with V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst [10–12]. Our group recently reported a promising Ce-Mo-O x catalyst, which exhibited superior activity in the temperature range from 200 to 400°C and high resistance to the H2O and SO2 poisoning [13]. Alternatively, Shen et al. found a novel CeO2/Al2O3 catalyst supported on an activated-ceramics and used for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3, which showed high activity in the temperature range from 250 to 350°C under the space velocity of 3000h−1 [14]. Guo et al. prepared CeO2/Al2O3 catalysts with single sol–gel, impregnation and coprecipitation methods to investigate the relationship between the preparation approach and the SCR catalytic activity, which exhibited that the single step sol–gel method had the best SCR activity in the temperature scope from 250 to 350°C under the space velocity of 25,000h−1 [15]. However, the tolerance to the SO2 and the reaction temperature window of Ce-Al based catalysts need to be further improved. In addition, MoO3 has been used as a stabilizer and promoter to enhance the NO x removal activity in the traditional V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for many years, where MoO3 could also provide high SCR activity compared to WO3 in flue gases containing arsenic oxides [16]. Lietti et al. found that the V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst exhibited higher reactivity with respect to V2O5/TiO2 or MoO3/TiO2 in a wide temperature range [17]. Therefore, MoO3 may be a good candidate to improve the NH3-SCR activity and sulfur-poisoning resistance for the Ce-Al based catalyst. In this study, a series of MoO3 modified CeAlO x catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method and used for the NH3-SCR reaction process. The evaluation results showed that the CeAlO x catalyst displayed low activity in the tested condition. However, MoO3 doped CeAlO x catalysts exhibited high activity in the temperature from 200 to 400°C, especially for the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst. The CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst not only exhibited high resistance to SO2 and H2O poisoning but displayed well resistance to the high GHSV. These experimental results indicated that the Ce-Mo-AlO x is a promising NH3-SCR catalyst to control NO x abatement. At the same time, the corresponding NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst was also proposed by applying the in situ DRIFTS analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and activity test The CeAlO x catalyst, with a Ce/Al molar ratio of 1:1, was synthesized by co-precipitation method using Ce(NO3)3·5H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O as precursors and 25wt% NH3·H2O as precipitator. The MoO3 doped catalysts were also prepared by the same method and marked as CeMo m AlO x , where the ‘m’ denoted the Mo/Al molar ratio, and m =0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2. The aqueous solutions of (NH4)6Mo7O24·5H2O with equal weight H2C2O4·2H2O were added into the deionized water. After the (NH4)6Mo7O24·5H2O was dissolved completely, the Ce(NO3)3·5H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were added into the aqueous solution with the required molar amount. Excessive 25wt% NH3·H2O solution was dropped into the mixed solution under vigorous agitation until pH 10. The precipitated solids were collected by filtration and washed with distilled water, followed by drying at 110°C for 12h and subsequently calcination at 500°C for 5h in the static air atmosphere. Finally, the catalysts were crushed and sieved to 40-60 meshes. For parallel test purpose, the Mo0.5AlO x catalyst and the conventional V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst with 2.5wt%V2O5 and 10wt%WO3 and were prepared by using impregnation method. After impregnation, the excess water was removed at 90°C, subsequently the sample was dried at 110°C for 12h and then calcined at 500°C for 5h in the static air condition. The SCR activity measurements were carried out in a fixed bed quartz reactor (inner diameter 10mm) under atmospheric conditions. A K-type thermocouple (o.d. 1mm) was directly immersed into the catalyst bed from the bottom of the reactor and connected to a programmable temperature controller to monitor the reaction temperature. The composition of the model flue gas was: 500ppmNO, 500ppm NH3, 5%O2, 5%H2O (when used), 100ppm SO2 (when used), balance N2, and 300mLmin−1 total flow rate, yielding a GHSV range from 25,000 to 100,000h−1 based on different volume of the catalyst. The water vapor was introduced by an injection pump (LSP01-1A, Longer Pump Inc) and an evaporator. The concentrations of NO and NO2 in the inlet and outlet gas were measured by an online chemiluminescent NO/NO x analyzer (Model KM9106, Kane Inc). The N2O concentration was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (FULI 9790, Zhejiang Wenling Inc) with a porapak Q column. The data were collected after 1h when the SCR reaction had reached a steady state. NO conversion and N2O selectivity were calculated as following [18]: NO conversion = NO x inlet − NO x outlet NO x inlet × 100 % ; with NO x = NO + NO 2 N 2 O selectivity = 2 N 2 O outlet NO x inlet − NO x outlet × 100 % 2.2 Characterizations The specific surface area, pore volume and the average pore size of the samples were obtained by N2 adsorption/desorption at 77K using a Micromeritics Tristar-3000 system. Prior to the N2 adsorption, the catalysts were degassed at 90°C for 1h and 300°C for 4h. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were determined by using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method under the 0.05–0.3 partial pressure range. The total pore volume and the average pore diameters were measured from the N2 desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The crystallinity of the catalysts were measured by means of powder XRD patterns obtained on a Rigaku D/max 2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, scanning between 10° and 90° at a step of 5°/min. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) profiles were measured by using a Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 instrument. For the H2-TPR, in each experiment a 50mg sample was loaded into the quartz reactor and pretreated in He (50mL/min) at 300°C for 1h. The sample was then cooled to room temperature under flowing He. The sample was reduced starting at room temperature and increasing up to 900°C in a gas mixture of 10% H2/He at 10°C/min. The consumption of H2 was monitored continuously by using a thermal conductivity detector. For the NH3-TPD experiments, after pretreatment in a He stream at 200°C for 1h, the catalysts were cooled down to 50°C and saturated with NH3 at a flow rate of 40mL/min for 1h, followed by flushing with He at 100°C to avoid physisorption of NH3. Desorption was carried out by heating the catalyst in He from 100 to 600°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Nicolet Nexus 670) equipped with an in situ diffuse reflection chamber and high sensitivity mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. An about 30mg sample was finely ground and placed in the in situ chamber. The mass flow controllers and temperature controller were used to simulate the reaction conditions. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was heated at 500°C for 30min in a flow of 10% O2/N2 and then cooled to 200°C. The background spectrum was recorded and subtracted from the sample spectrum. All the spectra were collected with an accumulating 100 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity test The NO conversion of the CeAlO x and MoO3 modified Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts with different Mo/Al molar ratios were showed in Fig. 1 a. It could be seen that the addition of MoO3 to the CeAlO x catalyst could increase the catalytic activity significantly. At 200°C, the NO conversion was greatly improved from 40.2% to 91.8% with an increase of Mo/Al molar ratio from 0.1 to 0.5. For the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst, little NO could be detected in outlet from 225 to 375°C. However, further increasing the Mo/Al molar ratio resulted in an obvious decline of the NO conversion in the tested temperature scope. In a summary, the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst exhibited the best NH3-SCR performance. The results of N2O selectivity in the NH3-SCR reaction over the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts were exhibited in Fig. 1b. It can be seen that little amount of N2O formed on the CeAlO x catalyst, especially at the lower temperatures. The increase of N2O selectivity at high temperatures was more evident on the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts with the increase of Mo content. However, the N2O selectivity was still maintained at a relatively low level with no more than 21% N2O selectivity attained during the measured period. The above results suggested that the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalyst had high N2 selectivity during the NH3-SCR reaction. In order to evaluate the SCR performance of the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalyst, the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst was chose as a model catalyst to compare with the prepared 2.5wt%V2O5-10wt%WO3/TiO2 catalyst under the GHSV of 50,000h−1. As showed in Fig. 1c, the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst exhibited high activity with more than 90% NO conversion from 250 to 400°C. As for the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst, the low temperature NH3-SCR activity presented much higher than that of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, especially below 300°C. Although the high temperature SCR activity above 350°C showed a little decrease, yet the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity in a wider operation temperature scope from 200°C to 400°C. Consequently, the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst is a promising candidate for the removal of NO. 3.2 The influence of GHSV on the NH3-SCR performance The influence of GHSV on NO conversion over the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst was investigated and the results were exhibited in Fig. 2 . Obviously, the increase of GHSV from 25,000 to 50,000h−1 only resulted in a little decrease of SCR activity below 225°C, but no distinct effect on the higher temperature activity. When the GHSV was further increased to 100,000h−1, the catalytic activity decreased significantly in the entire temperature range, especially below 250°C. However, more than 90% NO conversion was still attained during the temperature range from 225 to 400°C. The above results suggested that the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst is effectively resistant to the large space velocity. 3.3 The influence of H2O or/and SO2 on the NH3-SCR performance Since the SO2 gas and water vapor in the combustion exhaust often lead to the deactivation of the SCR catalyst. In order to investigate the influences of SO2 and H2O on the performance of CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst and better compare the activities with V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, the influences of 100ppm SO2 and/or 5% H2O on the performance of the CeMo0.5AlO x and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts were also studied at 250°C. The corresponding results were illustrated in Fig. 3 . For the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst system, when 5% water vapor was introduced into the stream, the NO conversion showed a slight decline during the tested period and after stopping it, the conversion was restored to 97.3%. The inhibiting effect of water on the SCR performance is due to the competition between H2O and NH3/NOx on the active sites or decreasing the pre-exponential factor and increasing the activation energy [19,20]. When the 100ppm SO2 was injected into the mixed gases for 4h, the NO conversion became stable. After removing SO2 the conversion was recovered to 96.5%. It can be found that the NO conversion decreased a little more compared with only 5%H2O. The deactivation of the catalyst caused by SO2 on the SCR performance can be attributed to the formation of (NH4)2SO3 or NH4HSO4, which deposited on the catalyst surface and then blocked the active sites [21,22]. When the 100ppm SO2 and 5% H2O were injected into the feed gases at the same time, the NO conversion decreased much more severely compared with only 100ppm SO2 or 5%H2O, however, more than 70% NO conversion still could be attained during the measured period. The poisoning reason not only could be connected with formation of ammonium salt on the catalyst surface but also related with the active phase was sulfated and then formed stable sulfate species, which was inactive in the SCR reaction [21]. In the meanwhile, it also could be found that the decreased range of NO conversion for the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst exhibited much more seriously compared with V2O5-WO3/TiO2 under the same tested condition. After removing the H2O or SO2, the conversion didn’t restore to its original level. However, the conversion was still maintained at a relatively high level. All the above analysis suggested that the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst had high SO2/H2O durability. 3.4 XRD and BET results The XRD patterns of the CeAlO x and Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts were displayed in Fig. 4 . From the figure it can be found that some peaks appear at 2θ =28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.0°, 69.5°, 76.9°, 79.2° and 88.5°, respectively, corresponding to the typical diffraction patterns of the Cerianite CeO2 structure. No visible phase of molybdenum species could be detected on the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts, which indicated that molybdenum oxide existed in a highly dispersed state or amorphous state. At the same time, no obvious alumina phase was observed at all catalysts. As the Mo/Al molar ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.5, the intensities of the CeO2 peaks occurred almost no changes, which indicated that the grain size of CeO2 on these catalysts were almost the same. However, further increasing the Mo/Al molar ratio to 2.0, the XRD patterns of CeO2 become sharper, which suggested that the grain sizes of CeO2 on CeMoAlO x and CeMo2AlO x catalysts were larger than that on CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst. This also meant that further increase the addition of molybdenum oxide could enlarge the grain size of CeO2 crystallinity and then lower the dispersion of CeO2 on the catalyst surface, which might be one reason for the lower NH3-SCR catalytic activity. The BET-surface area, total pore volume and the average pore diameter of the CeAlO x and Ce-Mo-AlOx catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . From Table 1, it could be seen that the introduction of Mo into the CeAlO x catalyst could decrease the surface area in different degrees, while the total pore volume and the average pore diameter were increased in various extents. The surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of CeAlO x were 160.83m2/g, 0.17cm3/g and 3.93nm, respectively. After doping with Mo, the surface area of the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst dropped to 117.93m2/g, while the pore volume and average pore diameter increased to the maximum 0.29cm3/g and 9.55nm, respectively. However, the physical parameters of the Ce-Mo-AlO x decrease gradually with further increasing the Mo/Al molar ratio, which might be connected with the growing size of the CeO2 crystallites. 3.5 H2-TPR results According to the redox mechanism for the SCR reaction proposed by Lietti et al. the reducibility of the catalyst is important for the NH3-SCR reaction [23]. In order to investigate the effect of Mo content doping on the reduction behaviors of the CeAlO x catalyst, H2-TPR profiles of the CeAlO x and Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts were presented in Fig. 5 . As can be seen in the figure, the TPR profile of the CeAlO x catalyst showed one broad reduction peak from 300 to 600°C corresponding to the stepwise reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ [24]. As for the Mo0.5AlOx catalyst, the peak at 596°C can be associated with the reduction of Mo6+. In the case of the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts, the profile of the CeMo0.1AlO x catalyst contained two reduction peaks. The first peak became narrower with a maximum at around 525°C, which was due to the reduction of the surface CeO2. The second peak at about 872°C can be attributed to the reduction of bulk CeO2. After normalization by BET surface area, the H2 consumption for the peaks was calculated and the values were listed in the inset of Fig. 5. As the Mo/Al molar ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.5, the H2 consumption was increased from 5.5 to 7.3, which suggested that the mobility of the surface oxygen was enhanced by the introduction of molybdenum. However, the intensity of the reduction peak and the H2 consumption decreased with further increasing Mo/Al molar ratio, indicating the decrease of the reducibility, which also is an important reason for the reduce of the NH3-SCR catalytic activity. 3.6 NH3-TPD results Apart from the reducibility of the catalyst, the surface acidity of the catalyst also plays an important role in the NH3-SCR reaction. Thus, the adsorption capacity of NH3 on the catalyst was characterized by NH3-TPD in the temperature range from 100 to 600°C. The corresponding NH3-TPD curves of the CeAlO x and Ce-Mo-AlO x catalysts were displayed in Fig. 6 . As can be seen from the figure, the desorption curve of the CeAlO x catalyst owned three peaks at 174°C, 280°C and 355°C, respectively. The peak at 174°C can be assigned to the weakly adsorbed NH3, the peaks at 280°C and 355°C can be attributed to the strongly adsorbed NH3. After normalization by BET surface area, the total acidity of the CeAlOx catalyst was 3.7μmol/gm2. After doping with Mo, the profile of the CeMo0.1AlO x catalyst changed significantly. The strongly adsorbed NH3 peak at 355°C disappeared and the total acidity increased to 5.0μmol/gm2, which suggested that the surface acidity of the CeMo0.1AlO x catalyst was enhanced by doping with Mo. This may be connected with that the ammonia is coordinatively held over Mo surface cation species and then protonated as NH4 + over Mo-OH on the catalyst surface [17]. As the Mo/Al molar ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.5, the position of the NH3 desorption peak was almost no change and the total acidity of the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst was increased to the maximum 6.5μmol/gm2. However, as the Mo/Al molar ratio was further increased to 2.0, the total acidity of the CeMo2AlO x catalyst decreased to 6.3μmol/gm2. Combination the NH3-SCR activity results with the NH3-TPD curves, it can be seen that the concentrations of surface acid sites on the catalyst surface played an important role during the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.7 In situ DRFTS results 3.7.1 In situ DRIFTS of NH3 or NO+O2 adsorption over CeAlO x and CeMo0.5AlO x catalysts In order to examine the changes of NH3 and NO+O2 absorbed on the surface of the catalyst after introduction of MoO3, the in situ DRIFTS of NH3/NO x adsorption over CeAlO x and CeMo0.5AlO x catalysts at 200°C were recorded and the corresponding results were exhibited in Fig. 7 . As showed in Fig. 7a, the bands at 1157, 1238, 1265 and 1620cm−1 are assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric deformation vibration of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid site [25–28]; the band at 1540cm−1 can be attributed to ionic NH4 + species on Brønsted acid site [28]. At the same time, the bands at 1320cm−1 and 1510cm−1 are due to the scissoring vibration mode of NH2 species [29,30]; a big negative band at 1522cm−1 is ascribed to the disappearance of NO3 −, which can be interpreted as transformation of nitrato (NO3 −) to nitrite (NO2 −) species upon the introduction of NH3 [31]; the bands at 3264 and 3365cm−1 are attributed to N–H stretching vibration modes [32]; some negative bands at 3645, 3710 and 3769cm−1 belonged to the surface O-H stretching were also detected [33–35]. After the addition of Mo, the negative bands and the bands assigned to the scissoring vibration mode of NH2 species disappeared obviously. However, the bands at 1182, 1282 and 1620cm−1 assigned to the Lewis acid site and the band at 1430cm−1 corresponding to the Brønsted acid site were much stronger than that on the CeAlO x catalyst [21,28,36,37]. The above analysis indicated that both the Lewis and Brønsted acid strength were increased by the introduction of Mo, which was consistent with the NH3-TPD result. Lietti et al. have reported that molybdenyls act as adsorption sites for ammonia, the increased Lewis acid sites are connected with the Mo oxide species and the increased Brønsted acid sites are related with the Mo-OH species [17]. In the mean time, much more bands attributed to N-H stretching vibration modes were also detected on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst. As showed in Fig. 7b, when the CeAlO x catalyst was exposed to NO+O2, some bands were detected. The bands at 1208cm−1 and 1592cm−1 are assigned to bridged nitrite and bridged nitrate, respectively [38,39]. The bands at 1248cm−1 and 1565cm−1 attributed to bidentate nitrate, and the bands at 1502cm−1 and 1539cm−1 belonged to the monodentate nitrate also appeared [40–43]. At the same time, a band at 1352cm−1 attributed to nitro species was also observed [44]. After introducing NO+O2 into the DRIFT cell, the intensity of the bands on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst showed a little decreased compared to the CeAlO x catalyst, some bands appeared at 1230, 1295, 1548, 1578 and 1601cm−1. The band due to nitro species was not detected, and the bands assigned to nitrate and nitrite shifted to the higher wavenumbers. These results suggested that the thermal stability of the adsorbed nitrate species become worse, and some monodentate nitrates were converted into bridged nitrate by the addition of molybdenum. In addition, the NH3 or NO+O2 adsorption on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst at different temperatures was also performed and the corresponding results were showed in Fig. 7c and d. The intensity of the most bands due to NH3 adspecies also decreased obviously, and the bands at 1169cm−1 and 1270cm−1 attributed to Lewis acid sites shifted to 1195cm−1 and 1293cm−1 with increasing the temperature, however, these two bands still remained at above 300°C, which indicated that NH3 bonded to Lewis acid sites were much more stable [45,46]. Similarly, all the bands attributed to NO x adspecies gradually became weaker with increasing the temperature and then disappeared at 350°C and 400°C, which indicated that the thermal stability of the adsorbed nitrate species on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst become poor. 3.7.2 In situ DRIFTS of the reaction between (a) NO+O2 and adsorbed NH3 species, (b) NH3 and adsorbed NO+O2 species (c) NH3 and NO+O2 over CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst Fig. 8 a showed the in situ DRIFTS spectra of the reaction between NO+O2 and adsorbed NH3 species on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst at 200°C. After NO+O2 passed over the NH3 pretreated CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst, the bands attributed to ionic NH4 + (1430cm−1), coordinated NH3 (1282cm−1 and 1182cm−1) and N-H (3182cm−1, 3268cm−1 and 3362cm−1) showed an obviously decrease in intensity and totally disappeared after 10min, nevertheless the band at 1620cm−1 assigned to Lewis acid site cannot be detected until the introduction of NO+O2 for 20min, and then the nitrate species began to form on the catalyst surface [28,32,36,37]. After the catalyst was purged with NO+O2 for 20min, some bands ascribed to bridged nitrite (1230cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1295cm−1 and 1548cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1578cm−1) and bridging nitrate (1601cm−1) were detected [39,46–48]. These results implied that both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites could react as reducing agents to catalytic reduce NO x in the NH3-SCR reaction, which also indicated that surface acidity plays an important role in the adsorption and activation of NH3, and thus further influence the performance of the NH3-SCR reaction. Contrastively, the reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO+O2 species was also performed on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst at 200°C and the results were exhibited in Fig. 8b. After NH3 passed over the NO+O2 pretreated CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst, the band at 1230cm−1 was shifted to 1246cm−1, which can be attributed to bidentate nitrate [40]. When the NH3 was introduced for 5min, the bands due to monodentate nitrate (1295 and 1548cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1578 and 1246cm−1) disappeared, however, the bridged nitrate (1601cm−1) still can be detected on the catalyst surface even after 60min, which indicated that the monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate were reactive and the bidentate nitrate was inactive in the SCR reaction. At the same time, the bands assigned to coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites (1182, 1255 and 1282cm−1), ionic NH4 + (1430cm−1) and NH2 species (1555cm−1) were rapidly detected on the catalyst surface, and three bands appeared at between 3100 and 3400cm−1 can be attributed to N-H stretching vibration in coordinated NH3 [21,32,36,37,49,50]. The formation of NH2 species indicated that the introduced NH3 was activated to NH2 species by the reaction with the adsorbed NO+O2 species, which was consistent with the result reported by Tanaka et al. [50]. In addition, the above analysis also suggested that NH3 and NO x can be adsorbed on the different active sites of the catalyst surface. In order to determine the species present on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst under the real NH3-SCR reaction condition, the in situ DRIFTS of the reaction between NH3 and NO+O2 was also carried out and the spectra results were displayed in Fig. 8c and d. As can be seen in Fig. 8c, after the NH3 and NO+O2 were introduced into the cell for 5min at 200°C, the bands due to adsorbed NH3 species (1182cm−1, 1282cm−1, 1430cm−1, 3100–3400cm−1 and 3600–3800cm−1) and the band at 1601cm−1 ascribed to bridged nitrate could be observed on the catalyst surface markedly [21,32,36,37,47]. Meanwhile, two very slight bands at 1549 and 1560cm−1 assigned to monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate also can be detected, separately [47,51]. However, the NH2 species were not appeared during the test period. As showed in Fig. 8d, the intensities of all the bands decreased noticeably with the reaction temperature increased, and almost bands disappeared at 250°C, while the band at 1601cm−1 assigned to the adsorbed NO x species still remained. This meant that the reaction between NH3 and NO+O2 was fast on the catalyst surface at above 250°C. All the above results implied that the bridged nitrate was inert; NH2 species, monodentate and bidentate nitrate were active intermediates on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst surface during the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.7.3 Possible reaction mechanism for the NH3-SCR reaction over CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst The mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction over different catalysts has been studied extensively, and different hypotheses have been proposed. However, the most accepted mechanisms are Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) and Eley–Rideal (E–R) [52]. Combination the previous research and the spectra analysis, a simplified reaction mechanism over CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst was proposed and listed in Fig. 9 . The adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst surface has been considered an initial step for the NH3-SCR reaction, which also has been confirmed by our in situ DRIFTS spectra. Besides, oxygen was decomposed into active monomolecular oxygen (O(ad)) by the surface active sites and the adsorption of NO on the catalyst surface were also important steps for the NH3-SCR reaction. On the one hand, the adsorbed NH3 species (NH4 + (ad), NH3 (ad)) could react with the adsorbed nitrate species (monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate) in the NH3-SCR reaction following the L–H mechanism below 300°C (Eq. (4)). On the other hand, the coordinated NH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface can be further oxidized into NH2 intermediate species and the retained NH3 adspecies, all of which could react with gas phase NO to form N2 and H2O following the E–R mechanism at above 300°C (Eqs. (5) and (6)). 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a serial of MoO3 doped CeAlO x mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method. Among all the MoO3 doped catalysts, the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst with Mo:Al molar ratio being 0.5 presented super NH3-SCR activity in a relatively wide temperature range from 200 to 400°C, and strong resistance to the high space velocity as well as anti-poisoning of SO2 or/and H2O. The introduction of Mo species could increase the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and prevent the formation of the stable nitrate on the catalyst surface. Besides, the oxidation–reduction ability of the catalyst was also enhanced by in addition of Mo, all of which are the key factors to increase the catalytic activity of the Ce-Mo-AlO x catalyst. A possible reaction mechanism was also proposed over the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A series of MoO3 doped CeAlO x mixed oxide catalysts with different Mo/Al molar ratios were prepared by the simple coprecipitation method and used for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The Ce-Mo-AlO x catalyst with the Mo/Al molar ratio of 0.5 exhibited excellent activity and high H2O or/and SO2 poisoning resistance at 250°C. XRD revealed that the molybdenum oxide existed in either highly dispersed or amorphous phases on the catalyst surface. BET analysis results showed that the total pore volume and the average pore diameter of the CeAlO x catalyst was improved by the addition of MoO3. As determined by the H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, the redox capacity and total acidity of the CeAlO x catalyst were also enhanced by the introduction of MoO3, which are critical for the NH3-SCR reaction. The SCR reaction mechanism was also studied by the in situ DRIFTS, the coordinated NH3 and ionic NH4 + species together with the monodentate and bidentate nitrate were active intermediates on the CeMo0.5AlO x catalyst surface during the NH3-SCR reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Molybdenum modified CeAlO x catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
